content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Find the ArXiv Blog on the ArXiv website and summarize the content of its latest article.  Please interact with https://arxiv.org/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: There is no visible link or button labeled "Blog" or any direct indication of the ArXiv Blog in the current viewport. The most likely location for blog-related links is either further down the page or in the site menus. I should scroll down the page to look for a "Blog" section or link.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: There is still no visible indication of an "ArXiv Blog" or any link related to a blog in the current portion of the page. The main categories for Physics, Mathematics, and Computer Science are displayed with their respective subfields. To find a blog link, it may be helpful to scroll down further, possibly to a website footer or a news/updates section.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The screenshot displays even more subject categories, but still there is no visible "Blog" or "ArXiv Blog" link or section. It is possible that the blog link is located further down the page, possibly in the website footer or another informational section. Continuing to scroll is the best way to find a navigation or informational section that may include the blog.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The bottom section of the homepage is visible, with several links under "About arXiv" and in the footer. There is still no explicit "ArXiv Blog" or "Blog" link. "General information" might contain information about a blog if it exists, as it's the most general and inclusive link here.
Action: Click 29
Confidence: 0.7
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The page is about "Submission Guidelines" for arXiv and does not provide any links or references to a blog. There is a search box at the top right (element 3). Using the search function to look for the term "blog" or "arXiv blog" could help directly locate any relevant blog sections or articles.
Action: Type 3; arXiv blog
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.45
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current page is "About arXiv," with several navigation links visible: "News," "Funding & Governance," "Membership & Giving," and "Who We Are." The "News" section (element 5) is the most likely place where blog articles or blog-related content might be posted, as arXiv might combine news and blog content.
Action: Click 5
Confidence: 0.92
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "arXiv Blog" link is now visible under the "News" section (element 9). Clicking this link should take me to the ArXiv Blog, where I can then locate and summarize the latest article.
Action: Click 9
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.7

content:
Thought: The latest blog article is titled "Attention Authors: Upcoming Scheduled Maintenance to arxiv.org," published on September 16, 2025. A short summary of the article is visible, but the full content may be accessible by clicking the "CONTINUE READING" button (element 9).
Action: Click 9
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.85

content:
Thought: The full article titled "Attention Authors: Upcoming Scheduled Maintenance to arxiv.org" is shown at the top of the page, with the author being Charles Frankston and the publication date as September 16, 2025. The start of the article content is visible, mentioning scheduled database maintenance and the specific downtime period, but the complete article content may extend further down the page. I should scroll down to view and summarize all the main points in the article.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.9

content:
Thought: The full content of the latest ArXiv Blog article is now visible. The article details scheduled maintenance for arxiv.org on September 17th, 2025, from 7AM to 9AM EDT. During this time, normal browsing and searching will be possible, but all functions requiring login (such as submissions and account management) will be disabled. The update is expected to take two hours, and users are directed to https://status.arxiv.org for updates.
Action: ANSWER; The latest article on the arXiv Blog is "Attention Authors: Upcoming Scheduled Maintenance to arxiv.org" by Charles Frankston, published on September 16, 2025. The article announces that arXiv's database will undergo scheduled maintenance on September 17th, 2025, from 7AM to 9AM EDT. During this time, users can browse and search papers, but all log-in dependent functions (like submissions and account edits) will be unavailable. The update is expected to last two hours. For ongoing updates, users are advised to check https://status.arxiv.org.
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 1.0
token: : ANSWER; The latest article on the arXiv Blog is "Attention Authors: Upcoming Scheduled Maintenance to arxiv.org" by Charles Frankston, published on September 16, 2025. The article announces that arXiv's database will undergo scheduled maintenance on September 17th, 2025, from 7AM to 9AM EDT. During this time, users can browse and search papers, but all log-in dependent functions (like submissions and account edits) will be unavailable. The update is expected to last two hours. For ongoing updates, users are advised to check https://status.arxiv.org
